titleStmt.title: Description of Aberystwyth NLW, MS 735 C

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation with pencil in the upper right corner: 1-47. Previous pagination with pencil marking every recto again in the upper right corner: 1-93.
supportDesc.collation: The manuscript comprises two codicological units. Part 1: I6 (ff.1-6), II4 (ff.7-10), III8 (ff.11-18), IV8(-6) (ff.19-20, lost 6 folia after f. 20), V6(ff. 21-26). Part 2: I-II8 (ff.27-34 and 35-42), III6 (ff. 43-48). Judging by the abrupt end of the final paragraph, the last quire is missing several folios.

condition.p: A large hole on f. 45 extending for 18 lines occured probably by the production of the parchment (text is written around it).

layout.p: ff. 1r-3r and 24v written in 2 columns, around 44 long lines. Rustic used for headings; Capitalis for incipit and explicit. Initials for opening paragraphs or sections. Red colour used to highlight incipit/explicit and fill up the initials and the majuscle at the beginning of sentences. The verses in Germanicus' Aratea begin with versals
ff. 5v-47v written in 1 columns, around 44 long lines.

handDesc.handNote: In Part 1 there are three main hands: Hand A copied ff.1r-16v and 21r-23r, Hand B ff.16v-20v, Hand C finished the text on ff. 23v-24v. Folio 2va, line 13 to the end of the page was copied by a firth hand.
Part 2 was copied by one main hand. Exceptions on ff. 38r-39r and 42v where two other hands join in for short sessions.

scriptNote.p: Both codicological part are written in caroline minuscule; Part 2 exihibts insular features.

binding.p: According to a note on the first garde folio the manuscript was rebbacked in the original blind-tooled 17th century English binding at N.L.W.

origin.p: Part 1 was copied around 1000 in the Limoges area (MsGurk) and came from the circle of Adémar de Chabannes (989-1034).
Part 2 was copied possibly in Wels (McGurk/Bischoff) in the mid 12th c.

provenance.p: The manuscript must have been in London in the 17th c., where it got its new binding.

acquisition.p: Arrived in the National Library of Wales in 1913 from Thomas Lloyd's family home.

msItem.author: Boniface
msItem.title: Carmina acrosticha
msItem.incipit: De veritate. Vincere me nulli possunt sed perdere multi
msItem.explicit: Falsior inter nos probatur nulla sororum.
msItem.bibl: MGH Poetae lat. aevi carol., pp. 6-14

msItem.note: Verse from the so called Appendix Vergiliana, De est et non.
msItem.rubric: Versus prisciani eloquentissimi viri de est et non incipiunt
msItem.incipit: Est et non cuncti monosyllaba nota frequentant
msItem.explicit: Qualis uita hominum duo quam monosyllaba uersant.

listBibl.bibl: Appendix Vergiliana. Ed. W. V. Clausen et al. Oxford: Clarendon, 1966.

msItem.note: Last five verses written in a pailer ink.
msItem.decoNote: In the lower half of the page schema with 3 trios of contrasting conditions in 9 lines "summum bonum, magnum bonum, bonum" , "creat et non creatur, creatur et non moritur, creatur et moritur" and "movet et non movetur, movetur tempore et non loco, movetur tempore et loco". From each of these nine conditions begins a line with text, which cross each other, so that from everygroup of three conditions the first, second and third are joined to one point.

Two drawings of the two hemispheres (divided by the colures) with the constellations and a band for the zodiacal ones. On f. 3v the illustrator left two unfinished circle diagrams, the one to the right having seven concentric circles. On f. 4r two figures, presumably Aratus receiving a crown from the muse Urania.

msItem.note: Verses with heading De circulo superiori, De circulo saturni, De circulo phetontis id est iovis, De circulo maultis id est martis, De circulo elyos id est solis, De circulo veneris id est luciferi, De circulo stilbontis id est mercurii, and De circulo lunae.
msItem.incipit: De cirylo superiori. Aplanes superam centron dixere priores
msItem.explicit: De circulo lunae. Primo luna gradu terrae confinialisque (?)
msItem.filiation: Rheims MS. 1263, 98v-99 (based on P. McGurk's description).
msItem.bibl: Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France : Départements, Reims, vol. 39, 1. Paris 1904, p. 360.
msItem.decoNote: Drawing of the zodiacal band in a circle, within which are drawn further circle with the planets. The circles for the Sun, Venus and Mercury crossing each other.

Unfinished drawings of the two hemispheres with the constellations this time the two circles are joined not at the side like in the previous drawing on f. 3v-4r, but are positioned so that the upper circle has its south pole up and north pole down, while the lower circle its north pole up and south down.
msItem.note: Around the drawings short texts almost illegible Sub pedibus nostris antarcticus iste iacebis Circulus hic nostris iugit subiectus ocellis. Contrariet et et gentes frigora uentos.

msItem.author: Ps-Cicero
msItem.title: In Sallustium
msItem.incipit: Ea demum magna uoluptas est C. Sallusti, aequalem ac parem uerbis uitam agere
msItem.explicit: sed ut ea dicam, si qua ego honeste effari possim.

msItem.author: Ps-Sallustius
msItem.title: In Ciceronem
msItem.incipit: Grauiter & iniquo animo maledicta tua paterer, M. Tulli, si te scirem iudicio magis quam morbo
msItem.explicit: neque in hac neque in ill parte fidem habens.

msItem.author: Ps. Priscianus
msItem.title: De sideribus
msItem.rubric: Incipit epitome phenomenon id est apparatio sive apparencia Prisciani grammatici versibus XII de sideribus
msItem.incipit: Ad boreę partes arcti uertuntur et anguis
msItem.explicit: Celsior his saturnus tardior omnibus astris.

msItem.author: Cicero
msItem.title: Somnium Scipionis
msItem.rubric: Somnivm scipionis M. Tulli Ciceronis excerptum ex libro VI. de re pvblica
msItem.incipit: Cum in afficam uenissem a manilio consule ad quartam legionem tribunus

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.title: Commentarium in Ciceronis somnium Scipionis
msItem.note: Four lines from the openning and closing of Book One.
msItem.rubric: Macrobii Ambrosii Theodosii viri clarissimi ex illvstris commentum ex Cicerone in somnivm scipionis
msItem.quote: Inter platonis et ciceronis libros quos de re publica quod ille rem publicam ordinauit, hic retulit. Sed hic inhibita continuatione disputationem sequencium reseruimus.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber I M. A. T. viri clari et illustris de somnio scipionis.

msItem.note: Another three lines from the opening and closing of Book Two (cap. 1, §1 and cap. 17, §17).
msItem.quote: Superiore commentario eustachi luce michi dileccior filiusque ad stelliferae spere cursum et subiectarum septem sermo processerat. Nunc iam de musico earum modulamini disputetur. Vere igitur pronunciandum est, nichil hoc opere perfeccius quo uniuersa philosophia continetur.

msItem.note: Drawing of planisphere with five concentric circles for the celestial zones and another band for the Zodiac. Skillful depictions of the constellations within the circles.

msItem.author: Germanicus
msItem.title: Aratea (Family O)
msItem.incipit: Ab ioue principium magno deducit aratus
msItem.explicit: (23r)Quod sine nube caua solis uia forta latebit.

msItem.title: Scholia Basileensia
msItem.incipit: Quertur quare ab ioue cepit et non a musis ut omerus.
msItem.explicit: aeffusum est lacte facta est circuli albi species.

msItem.incipit: Iuppiter est illo laeto magis hic ubique solis
msItem.explicit: haec eadem tibi signa dabunt non irrita pisces.

msItem.finalRubric: T. Claudii Cesaris phenomena explicit feliciter deo gratias.
msItem.decoNote: Illustrations of the constellations (on ff. 12r, 13r-15r, 16r, 17r-v, 18v-21v) and on f. 11v Aratus and Urania pointing to a globe, f. 12r Zeus with an eagle.

msItem.note: Drawing of a planisphere this time the constellations are marked with labels within the celestial circles.

msItem.title: De astronomia

msItem.explicit: annum voluerunt esse cum sol ab estivo circulo redeat.
